I went to NHA today for a volunteer info session!  And I'm so excited to help out!  For anyone who has spare time and loves cats or dogs, please contact Celia Gregory, the volunteer coordinator at volunteer@nashvillehumane.org or 615-354-6345.

You can help in many ways!  This includes walking dogs, cuddling with puppies and kittens, socializing cats, grooming cats and dogs, doing office work, working at adoption events, fostering animals, grant writing or fundraising, transportation of the Teddy mobile shelter, adoption aide volunteer, Working on the pet food bank, Wednesdays pet visitations to the elderly, etc.  They also have the Rover bus that fixes cats and dogs.  They come to various neighborhoods and sometimes partner with other local animal rescues like the Pet Community Center to offer low-cost spay/ neuter.

This shelter is very clean and the animals are so sweet. Come visit!  Adopt your new best friend today!

* Side notes:
1. If you visit the shelter often, one perk of being a trained volunteer is that you can go to the shelter when its closed to the public on Wednesdays and before hours!
2. If you are considering adopting, but aren't quite sure that you are ready, you can foster first and if you fall in love with the cat or dog, you get first dibs on adopting him or her!

You'd think for a place called "Brodo" that you'd be able to get a decent cup of soup.  Well, you'd be wrong.  I stopped in today after trying to get into Nom Nom (which was mobbed and they don't offer take out.  WTH?  But that's another review...)

Brodo looks very sleek, new and nice.  Prices seem low enough - but it ends there.
I got a 1/2 sandwich (Veggie) and a cup of soup (their version of Italian Wedding).  I asked if I could substitute cheddar for the American Cheese (which is a waste of tasteless fat/calories) and was told they only have shredded cheddar - but i could get swiss or provolone.  So I opted for no cheese.

Meanhwile, I start to eat it back at the office and there is a weird horse-radish taste to the mayo.  I think they goofed and put horseradish mayo on it.  Weird - but not bad.

The soup was salt-laden and NOT even close to being delicious.

Not goin' back.
Sorry.

I spent $8.40 for the combo (no drink).
Oh, and the line waas not bad when I went - but if there is a long line, don't wait in it.  NOT worth it.

So sad, because it looks very nice.  I sure do miss the Naked Chocolate Cafe though.

Comfort food of a food truck delivered to a deep South Tampa cafe. And if for some reason you don't like tater tots or want to go healthy, you can go with salad as a base. Fun featured tater tot speciald to choose from including Greek and BBQ with mac n cheese. Fun. Quirky. Pink. Nice outdoor seating area that is sunny but dog friendly. Very near the Interbay Meat Market and the lobster on a stick place.

Katy Perry, kissed a  girl and liked it. I had a McRib sandwich and didn't like it. 

The other day on my way to work without a lunch the morning DJ's were talking about the McRib and the limited availability. In all the years McRib has been offered, I have never tried it. With it's departure from the menu coming up soon and the positive spin one of the DJ's gave, I thought I'd try one for lunch. 

I ordered a McRib combo meal with a small french fry and small coke. Kevin the DJ, said he orders his without pickle and onions. I like pickles and onions, so I kept them on mine. I'm glad that I did, the bun along with the crisp pickles and onions were the best thing about the sandwich. The processed meat was tasteless, it was over sauced with a BBQ that was way to sweet. I thank my luck stars that I had an order of fries. I only wished I had upgraded to a larger size to fill the void left by a flavorless sandwich. 

This is a very clean and friendly McDonald's. I will not lower their star rating due to a seasonal sandwich that I did not enjoy. However, I would not recommend a McRib to anyone, not even my worst enemy.

With emergency rooms being overrun Mercy has a hard job on its hands.  Unless you are carried in it will take a minimum of 3 hours to get in and be seen.  While I was waiting there were three incidents where security had to be called to settle people down.  The reason is everyone wants to be first and not wait your turn.  So they go to squeaky wheel will get me in before everyone else.  When that does not work it really gets bad.  One person near me was on his cell phone telling whoever was on the other end of the phone that if he is not seen now he will become violent.  And of course hello security.

After entering the ER it took me from 4:PM to 1 AM to get admitted to the hospital proper.  This is only due to the vast overload.

During my wait I had stickers put on my wrist, an IV put in my arm, urine sample before I was in the ER room.  So they are doing the best they can.  Once in the ER room within 20 minutes I was taken for a Cat Scan.  By the time I got back in the room with not much wait  I was told I have an infection and they saw the problem on the Cat Scan.  The diagnosis was correct and treatment started while I was in the ER room.

Now off to the room and the hospital.  Nurses run hospitals as everyone knows.  Doctors come in and talk to you for 5 minutes and in terms no normal person understands.  It is up to the nurse to follow up talk to you and administer your care.

I was at first not allowed any form of liquid just an IV of glucose and my antibiotic.  Thirst is an amazing thing when you can't have a sip of water.  But I was allowed to swish some water around in my mouth.  Ah relief.  Latter I was moved to a clear liquid diet.  Water, broth, and a clear diet sprite and Jello.

Diet Jello never tasted so good.  5 star diet Jello. :).

I came to understand if I did not eat or want to eat something I was not getting out.  So the nurse convinced me after 3 days to try cream of wheat.  And see if I could handle it.  I passed with flying colors.  Within three hours of cream of wheat I was on my way home with 18 days of antibiotics.

I have diverticulitis.  I have had it before but this was in a different place and 100 times more severe.

In closing why five stars?  I understand the problems these noble nurses and doctors are putting up with and wanted to show my understanding.

ps 
Mrs. K (the saint) being Easter purchased the nurses an amazing amount of candy.  She did not tell me and all these people were coming in and thanking me for the candy.  In my fever and pain I was so confused.  I swear Mrs. K. likes to mess with me.  LOL!!
Their low fat mango smoothie was refreshing this time around. Their wifi is good as gold. Everyone is nice, and it's comfy here.  All is well.

Do you like meat that you can throw into a crock pot to cook, while you are at work?  Do you want to pay a low price for said meat?  Well, look no further!

What a great place!  They have everything you could ever want, including fantastic roasts.  The prices are reasonable and the food is good.

Three and a half stars. Clean bathrooms, great service from our bartender Sean. The barback tried to dissuade me from attempting their not-very-advertised challenge even as he shucked my oysters. Live music some evenings. My cocktail was on the sweeter side of okay, so I ended up sticking to the conservative beer list. Smoked fried oysters were plated on a leaf of butter lettuce with a pool of garlic aioli, and I barely got a hint of smoke flavor even when eaten naked. I was more pleased with the fried chicken livers that were served on a bed of bacon marmalade to minimize texture phobia. Good crunch on both menu items. Future hit list: house made gator sausage, pork butt tamale, spiced oyster taco, chicken & house made andouille gumbo, shrimp & roasted eggplant soup, shrimp & grits, fisherman's stew.

Food challenge: 12 local oysters with a heaping tablespoon of their hottest Beaver horseradish on each, to be eaten in 60 seconds without aid of a beverage.
Reward upon completion: one free beer, the oysters get comped, and a hilarious t-shirt in your size that says "I ate hot beaver ...at Grand Isle."
Status: completed, 60 seconds.
Advice: don't eat dinner beforehand, don't chew too thoroughly, and be prepared for ten minutes of hyperactive tear gland production, fifteen minutes of initial regret before you start mumbling that it was totally worth it (nigh disrespectful to the tasty oysters to down them that fast), an hour of tummy cramps and fermented burps to follow.

Exactly how the decision was made to come here, I could not recall at the time. We lyfted there. He said, "It's unusual that I don't know where we are going. Generally, I make the reservation and I pick the restaurant." The restaurant was quiet for a week night. We were led to the window table. He marveled at the seating selection. There were two best seats in the house. He said. One in the middle but with a bit of privacy. The other by the window. The one in the middle was already taken and we were given the window seat, aka the best seat in the house that was available. I took a mental note. 

Philadelphia has adopted a lot of New York style dining. Prix Fixe menu was abundant. Sbraga offers a $55 per head, four course meal. For what they serves up, it's an incredible deal. 

Gruyer popover and foie gras soup to start. Rich and flavorful. 

Hamachi ceviche next. It might be the best I've ever consumed in my life. Lamb tartare had a middle eastern flair to it. Very inventive. The next dish is a pasta dish, jerk lamb bolognese and spaghetti with blue crab were incredibly flavorful.

Ordinarily we'd have enough to eat but we continued with the entree. He opted for surf and turf and I had the fish. It's interesting when you have so many creative dishes on the offering, the dining options essentially become a careful balancing act between what you had previously had and what you would have on the next dish. We were deeply satisfied with our mains. The dessert choices were relatively easy. Sweet corn turnover and cheese.

Cheese course as the last dish is brilliant, and thankfully, this being Philly, they don't charge you extra. Most European restaurants offer cheese course as a dessert course. Nice to have them to include it. 

We did not spend a lot of time talking. We ate. And we ate.

Sbraga's Top Chef is gifted, crafty and creative.  The attention to detail and the use of varied ingredients were better than an above average pricy San Francisco restaurant. When I worked in Philly in the 90s, I remembered the food was already fanciful. It only improved more ever since then. Just then, it dawned me that Sbraga is listed as one of the 38 essential restaurants in Philly by Eater, and that's how I made the reservation. 

Satisfied, I expressed my interest in coming back here. He interpreted it as my general endorsement of Philly, which he frequented for work.  "Will you come back with me?" He asked. When I did not answer straight away,  the question became a statement: "You are coming back with me."

People!! Make sure u clear a whole bunch of time in your appointment book. The wait on a Sunday afternoon was almost an hour and a half from walking in the door to getting my ice cream in hand. My end of line wasn't at the door at the time so those people had to have waited longer. 

Yes, it's brand new and there's nothing like it yet elsewise, so there's the justification of the hype.

At least I talked to everyone waiting in line around me, & we were all in the same boat! 

It was really good when I finally got my order. It was #11 Kaka crunchy with Nutella and cereal ice cream and my toppings were kit kat, m and m, and fresh strawberry. My sauces were strawberry and caramel.

I'm glad I tried it and the price was okay, but still... that wait?! Wow!

It's all about those tri-tip sandwiches, especially when you add their barbecue and horseradish with whole grain mustard sauces. 

The meat is so juicy and it comes in thick slices on a French roll (photo: http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/0qu0fNTOsSmuREYVIMPuIQ?select=tnnvZS4u8Bw5KD1wvCsTVQ#gLpZVlHKwa1YGOdOHW_JSA). Incredibly satisfying, and they're only available Saturday and Sunday. 

Pick up your tickets in the storybook, ivy-covered cabin, with animal heads on the walls (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/0qu0fNTOsSmuREYVIMPuIQ?select=lNqGTkScbnCPArR2GEZShg#-wlmZ-b35UJ-GY-59NDxyw) and guns over the stone fireplace (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/0qu0fNTOsSmuREYVIMPuIQ?select=lNqGTkScbnCPArR2GEZShg#tnnvZS4u8Bw5KD1wvCsTVQ). Head around back and trade your ticket for a fistful of bread and meat. 

It doesn't seem like much as first, but it's easily the best steak sandwich I've ever had and just enough to feel satisfyingly full and yet not sick. The combination of horseradish sauce (which was flavorful and, thankfully, not particularly spicy) and barbecue sauce make it all the more irresistibly potent. 

This is now the sandwich against which all other tri-tip sandwiches shall be measured. 

Cold Spring Tavern's origin dates back to 1886 when it served as a stagecoach stop. With its small grouping of buildings of varying historic value, it's comparable to Arizona's Tortilla Flat, which was also a coach stop for changing horses and taking a rest or grabbing a meal.

They're supposedly noted for their more gamey meats like venison, elk, buffalo, pheasant, rabbit, and wild boar. In the past they've also served lion, kangaroo, and bear.

I've never seen a "super center" that is this small. 
It lacks a cohesive plus size clothing center - heck what used to be their plus wear is mostly clearance now.  They do have a decent electronics department, if you have an Iphone. A fairly OK selection of Health & Beauty.  But this is mostly a Walmart if you need to quick stop. There's a real super center 20 minutes away on SR54 or JUST up the road on Alderman.

While the Shops At Liberty Place offer an architecturally interesting structure in a modern urban environment, and attracts people for both shopping and sightseeing the latest in city planning, it also likely represents a business model that will not succeed in the long run.  

The suburban mall made its presence felt as a post World War II phenomenon that mirrored the rapid growth of the automobile industry and the closely aligned migration of a generation of city dwellers into the countryside, a/k/a Suburbia.  They were the successful way to provide the "stuff" of life away from the urban core.  They worked well for almost 50 years.  But, as with most things, they were overdone, and failed to adapt to the changing demographics and cultural evolution that they spawned.  Walk through most malls today and you see lots of empty space, failing stores, and a subculture of youth versus elderly hangouts.  

First the malls disrupted Main Street.  Then the Walmarts and Costco's of the world, disrupted the malls.  But, the disassociation from the communities where the consumer lived ultimately started to alienate them.  People wanted to return to their Main Street where possible.  More began to appreciate the quality of city life, and returned to the urban centers to once again live and work in the same place.  The suburbs began to lose its charm for many, especially those without young children.  

These reurbanified folk did not want to shop in malls along an inhuman highway, and certainly did not want to spend much time in a suburban style mall transplanted in the city.  The developers who thought otherwise, are wishing they had been smarter.  The retail franchisers and chain expanders were the last to catch on, but the growing list of failing stores and malls bear witness to this truth.  

So it is with the Shops of Freedom Place.  Fundamentally, a suburban marketplace miscast as a modern upscale urban experience that it turned out not enough people really wanted.  A J. Crew in a Center City suburban style mall just does not attract enough customers.  Never will. 

It is not that such a public space could never work.  It can, but it requires a total reconfiguration that demonstrates an understanding of what people really want.  What is that?  A return to the village life, or that of the old neighborhood, where people knew each other, and felt like part of a community - in the city.  More impersonal and monotonous shopping is not where we are headed.  

How accomplish that?  Start by thinking in human scale.  Change part of the Liberty Place skyscrapers into condos and apartments for people to live.  Add a supermarket, cinema, child care, medical facility, and more greenery throughout the buildings.  Create a vertical village or neighborhood.  Where are the green grocer, the deli, the bakery, the corner tavern? 

The central rotunda can still work as a gathering place for activities, but it should feel more like the gazebo in the middle of the public commons.  

People want their cities to be state of the art, cutting edge, and full of energy and opportunity.  But, they also want to feel like it can take care of their needs and make them feel part of it, not overcome by it.  There are examples of this being done successful around the country and the planet.  Visit some of the new cities in Asia, and even some of the new age projects in New York, Seattle(JB) and San Francisco.  

Bring it down to human scale, and they will come and thrive.

Whole Paycheck, yes, it is.  I stopped in quickly and just picked up a few items plus 2 pizza slices, and I spent nearly $50. Gulp. Their bottled tangerine Italian sodas are totally addicting, so I treat myself to them if I come here.  And I must say, I still really love their pizza. Their special was 2 slices for $7.

Free good wifi and yes, they make it really easy to stop after shopping to enjoy eating and relaxing here.

So, I've been waiting over a month now for that refund and haven't gotten it and they're not responding. So, yeah, that clinches it. Thanks for promising a solution to the problem and not following through.

There was certainly  no shortage of things to see on this tour . . .sadly none of them were alligators as the water was still too cold for them to be frolicking about.  And if you have your heart set on seeing and touching a baby alligator like they show on their website, you may also be disappointed as there are not enough for all the boats to have one.  Some people on our tour (from Australia, no less) had their hearts set on it and the tour guide acted like he didn't know what they were talking about!

The tour itself, was fun.  A couple of hours in the sunshine on a boat?  What could be wrong with that?  And we did see a few turtles, an egret and 3 snakes (not the highlight of my trip, I must add)  And it was too early in the season for mosquitoes too so that was a win!

But it was so busy back on the bayou that we had to keep backing up to let other boats pass and the quantity of marshmallows that were floating in the water made me wonder why they were pitching marshmallows at the alligators- last I checked meat would have been a better idea but maybe the economy hit the alligator feeding too!

The $49 tour ($43 if you book it on line) will get you picked up at your hotel in their bus and admission to the boat tour.  If you have your own car- it's only $25.  If I had to do it again- I'd probably rent a car just so I didn't have to hear the crazy tour that the bus driver gave us on the 45 minute drive to the swamps.

He kept talking and offering up things like "Katrina . . . . .as seen on CNN, and the weather channel, this is the bridge that people were walking on . . .as seen on CNN"  or having us note the large amount of closed car dealerships that were closed around the route (I can show him a similar amount of closed dealerships in most states that didn't have a Hurricane).  But the real irritant was as we were driving along the interstate- he would suddenly swerve over to the side of the road and stop to show us some water where he would say, "See . . . .no one is reck-creating today as there are gators in those waters"  Urrgh.  After 45 minutes of this I had a headache!  And I kept thinking we were going to be rear ended on the freeway!!

And know that you go back on the bus that you came on so remember the number. So we got to spend more time with this guy.   If the "reck-creating" wasn't enough- on the way back we went by a space shuttle from the very well known launch pad in "Cape COD".  Really?  I didn't know that Provincetown was launching rockets these days!

Friendly, for sure, but I personally preferred the statically radio playing disco songs to the constant chatter of this guy.

Go for the boat ride- it's worth it and a great way to spend a sunny afternoon.  But if you take the bus- bring ear plugs.  You'll thank me later.

Needed tags for my 3. Pick them up at check-out, then go to the kiosk to engrave. An interesting laser process, but you're in control all the way. Just have to get used to it.

Also, I needed a  backpack for my rescue dog, who likes to get out ALL THE TIME. He weighs 9 pounds. I'm fenced. Nonetheless, he finds incredible ways to get out.

So I got him a backpack and found the largest squeaky balls that fit into the backpack to give him more girth.

At checkout, the clerk started to take the balls out of the backpack, and I yelled, "No! I just got them to fit!" He got it, and scanned them.

They haven't left the "Outward Hound" backpack since! And Thomas Raymond hasn't gotten out!!! The whole point!

We stopped by Tria for after-dinner drinks following after a particularly filling dinner at Morimoto. I ordered a Greek red (Xinomavro) and it was excellent. The service was lax, but attentive at the same time. I particularly enjoyed the vibe of this place; it's where I would love to have a first date. It's comfortable, intimate, and has a great selection of nibblers, wine, and beer.

Take your girl (or guy) out here for a Friday night glass (or five!) of wine and see where the night takes you.

I am huge LUSH fan and this store is one of my favorites in the US. It's location in the Quarter is great and I always stop by to pick up a few items while I am in NOLA. The size of the store is perfect - enough room to get around even with a few people and (the many) employees in the store. I have found the service here to be great without being suffocating and I really appreciate that. Thanks LUSH NOLA!

My friend and I came here on a Thursday night and it was dead until midnight but even so at the most it had 10 people dancing on the dance floor. However, the DJ did an amazing job. He did an fantastic blend of hip-hop and electronic. There's also a patio outside in which you can go out and down to the beach. Also, some guys were bothering us but the security guards took care of them. There was also no cover charge for ladies that night. Overall a good experience. :)

If you're a night owl like me, you might find yourself drawn to Frank Relle's special kind of photography. It seems to all be done during the late night/early morning hours, while the rest of the world is asleep.

There are some haunting pieces in his work, and one of my favorites is that of a cemetery and another is of a lone moss tree in the middle of a deserted bayou. When lit correctly, these photos take on another dimension and certainly tell a captivating story. There is something a bit mysterious about photos such as these, and they are right up my alley.

When I was here for Dirty Linen Night, I was greeted by the gallery manager, who was quite friendly despite the crowd. The photos are well priced and could easily be added to any collection and find a spot in any home.

I've stayed here on 3 separate occasions and it's a very fine hotel.

You have Ruth's Chris for the steak lovers, Red for the trendy types, Brewhouse for those who want a gastropub or just want to watch the game.  Morning?  Don't worry, there's a Starbucks!

Valet is only $5 more than garage parking, and frankly, with this location, you gotta expect to pay a premium for parking.  At a hotel this nice, across the street from the Old Courthouse and Arch, you can't expect the "low price leader."

Yes, I don't like the nickel-and-dime aspect of paying for wi-fi, but I think this probably speaks to the Hyatt's convention and business traffic.  They know they can get away with it, so they do.  If you really need internet, walk to Bread Co.  It's a few minutes away and free there.

Rooms are clean and for the conferences, both big and small that I attended here, the meeting rooms were vast, spacious, well-appointed, and set-up just as ordered.  

I think this is a great spot to treat yourself if you live out in West County - walk to the game and come back to hang out after knocking a few down at Paddy O's.  Not paying for the DUI might be worth the cost of the room :-)

This is a good Asian food (Chinese) market. There are some branch locations now. They have some live and not so alive seafood. Sometimes they have good deals on various produces. Lots of noodle offerings. Snacks. Patel Brothers for Indian foods across the street is cool too while you're in the area. I actually prefer Sanwa and Oceanic in Tampa Heights is another good alternative, although a bit more spendy. Try something new?

The Bluffs on Broadway is a very unique event space located on the river bluff, just south of downtown St. Louis and the Anheuser Busch Brewery.  It holds about 75 seated at tables and/or 200 for a cocktail party.  The interior is contemporary with lots of whimsical art.  They have several decks, including two  that overlook the Mississippi river.

My only complaints about BOB is that parking is limited and it is pricey to rent/feed your guests.  However, if you have the budget and want something unique, you won't be disappointed.

It's so pretty!!! Is the staff nice? Nope! But, it's pretty :) Also, it's very easy travel. 

I appreciate the drive thru drop off zone but do with it was longer or wider, it's a bit tough during peak holiday travel with people driving thru like maniacs. (confession, I am most likely categorized as one of those maniacs) 

The only time I use this station is to hop on up to NYC and it's a super easy ride. It's 1 1/2 hours and you have time to sit back and relax while charging your phone in the outlet next to your seat, score! The seats are huge so you have tons of personal space. 

They still have an old school board to show departure times and stairways. Love the sound it makes. I could stare at the ceiling for hours too. The architecture is stunning. It's very open and not stuffy and they keep it very clean. 

I appreciate the shopping they have in here too, great spot to grab a book and a snack while you are waiting. 

A lovely experience. I truly can't imagine driving to NYC again.

The was a reason why this BK was practically empty when I stopped in for a quick breakfast the other day.  

The Biscuit for my sandwich was hard and too small to enclose its contents.  It appeared to be a tube biscuit that had been made earlier and left in the open air to dry out, and then microwaved just before sale.  It rehardened quickly and was a crumbly mess to eat.  Just not very good, despite the fact that the rest of the ingredients seemed fresh.  

Given the competition across the street, it is difficult to see how this place survives. Maybe their burgers are better, but I won't be back to find out.

I stayed here a couple nights this week, my most recent trip to Philly.

What I liked most about this place was how absolutely incredibly wonderfully dog-friendly it is, from early morning to late at night, from absolutely every person who works here (the guys in the parking garage, the guy who held the door, the concierge, the front desk people, the guy who helped with suitcases, the people who work in the bar, the guy who was cleaning the carpets, the woman who brought towels, the guy who brought soap, etc) -- there was no forced-smile contrived patronizing WHO'S A GOOD BOY cold-hearted patting on the head, my little buddy would've snapped at 'em, he hates insincerity just as much as I do -- they even gave him his own water bowl and food bowl and place mat and poop-bags and dog-tag, all to keep and take home... This aspect was awesome...

As for everything else, it was fine -- a little anonymous and corporate feeling, a little generic perhaps, not necessarily the most luxurious or posh, but they do their best to make you feel warm and welcome -- and the location was awesome -- nowhere I went or winded coming back from was more than a few blocks away... I'd definitely return!

Famished all day, I was on a mission to find a new place to eat, but something fairly close to home. I felt adventurous, but NOT that adventurous to go too far.

After living in the Tower Grove area for nearly 2 years, I finally decided to give Black Thorn a shot. All I've heard were good things minus the long wait people usually endure when coming here.

Jason and I got here around 7:30. To our surprise there was not a line nor was it insanely busy like we had anticipated. Another thing we had not anticipated was the set up of the place.

You have to place your order at the bar, get your own drinks from the bar, and pay all before you receive your pizza if you aren't going to keep an open tab. It basically has the same concept as a Bread Co. or Qdoba. Once you order, they'll bring you your pizza out.

We ordered a 12 inch Chicago style sausage and pepperoni pizza and a bowl of caesar salad to hold us over until the pizza came out. Little did we know that we were going to wait 30 minutes to receive the salad, then an additional 30 minutes after that for our pizza. As mentioned before, it was not busy. It had a few patrons, but not enough to cause the wait like we had to.

8:30pm. Pizza is out. We're ready and holy hot damn, am I excited! The pizza lived up to the hype I had hoped for. The time spent waiting was well worth every bite I ate. I think the only downside is the wait time. I don't know how long it takes to cook the pizzas. I'd assume awhile considering how thick the crusts are, but still, could they not have told us?

As far as the attitude of the bartender, I have to agree with Aimee K. The girl looked like she had a blank stare on her face, and she didn't seem too pleasant to talk to. I asked her when our salad was going to come out, and her reply was, "when we get to it." I went back to my seat and continued to wait without questioning. I didn't want anything to happen to our beloved deep dish pizza!

Anyway, aside from that, I like Black Thorn. The rustic looking 1980s dive bar setting who outlived its hay day truly adds character to this place. It has darts, hurling, and a juke box. You can't go wrong, especially in this hipster neighborhood.

Come check it out and you'll see what I mean.

Came in for my 5-6 month prophy and saw Kara - who is a new hygenist and TERRIFIC.  She took text-book perfect bitewings (digital, baby!) and Dr. D is great as always. Plus I love LeeAnn (sp??) - the office manager.  Such a well-run place!

Plus I got strawberry prophy paste.

Wheeeeeee!

Drive thru.  I asked for cheese.  Why didn't you give me the cheese I asked for?  I ordered chili.  EVERY time I've ordered Chili i've gotten the hot packet of sauce with it.  Why not this time?  I don't know.  The side salad and the chili were fine.  I know why get all bent out of shape just for a mistake?  Well, I guess it's just that I got my order in less than 30 seconds.  So maybe they should slow down just a little bit and actually double check the order.  Not very hard.  Three line items total on my receipt.
We started in the bar with drinks. The bartender was incredibly knowledgeable; he was a true professional. Then we moved to the table. Service was perfect. Food was ok. The place was pretty dead.

So upset I do not know where to begin.
I will call the store later today and try to get my issues resolved, but basically they wanted to do $1300 - $1400 worth of (according to my dealer) un-needed repairs and they did a shoddy job on my oil change.

I would up paying for a 2nd oil change and a completely different roster of repairs at the dealership.

I am very hesitant to ever come back here.

Most choices were really great (avoid the chickenparm - awful.) like my crab-stuffed ravioli, over broccoli rabe.  St. Louis Ribs were fall-off-the bone tender.

There is a slight "SYSCO" pre-fab element to the food - but for the most part we love a nice weekend lunch here.  Burgers (patty melts, southwest style) are a solid choice.  Upgrading to Sweet potato fries is a good idea!

3.5

We came in on a mid-week night.  It was a little strange that the number of diners in the restaurant (four) were far outnumbered by the number of staff who seemed to just stand around listlessly.  It felt a bit awkward and made the ambiance, I'm sorry to say, a bit grim.  

I ordered a combination platter of souvlaki and gyros which was pretty good for $12.50.  We also ordered a hummus plate as a starter and it was also tasty.  Service was good, if not muted. 

I've been to a lot of Greek restaurants and they are usually festive and happy places with a lot of laughter and a vibrant air.  This was not one of them.  On the plus side, conversations could be easily heard between diners, so no need to shout to each other in order to have a conversation.

usually i am NEVER disappointed by this RIDICULOUS old-fashioned treat... however, i got a concrete this last time that i didn't like so much. (note to self-- always get what YOU want, not what your husband wants... hehe.) 
it's affordable, it's delicious, and you feel swept back to the 50's... when signs and menus were handwritten and people were friendlier.

This is a good place for bread and desserts but the sandwiches are just NOT so good.  I'm not a big carb person and prefer the protein parts of my meal the most with lots of veggies on the side so this place isn't my optimal feeding spot.  Better to grab some bread to go and work your own magic on it.  They also offer some traditional Jewish breads that you might not find anywhere else in the area.  I never tried any of the Jewish breads and don't have any point of comparison to know if they are good or not but they looked nice.  The desserts here look pretty tasty and I had a cherry mini-pie that was pretty decent.  Overall I just wasn't that impressed and haven't been back for a long while now.

At 9:30am on a Saturday, when the rest of downtown Santa Barbara is pretty quiet, this spot is packed - and for good reason!

The line to order wasn't long, just a few people. We waited a few minutes and were able to get a table - meant for 4, but we got enough chairs to squeeze 6 chairs around it. 

THE COST: $29 for three small bowls.

Note: The "Small" is still a decent sized bowl! We were afraid what the "Large" would have looked like. If you want what would be, say a "Large" at Pinkberry, then get the "Kid's Size". The "Small" did keep us full for several hours!

* Island - 4 stars
This is more heavy on the berry/tart flavors, and the toasted coconut on top is a treat!

* Cocoa Almond - 3.5 stars
Definitely sweeter, between the chocolate base and the banana. This would've been too much sweet on its own if I weren't sharing the Island with my friend!

Where else in the area can you visit a steampunk-decorated coffee shop? Nowhere as far as I know! We were in the area so I stopped here and got some coffee drinks to go. I enjoy Kahwa espresso so I was pleased to see that's what they serve at Grindhouse! They seemed to have a wide variety of desserts in the case and they looked scrumptious but I've been eating healthy lately so I managed to resist.

Speaking of resisting... I have to admit, the whole time, I looked around nervously, waiting for perhaps a Scientologist to attempt to assimilate me. This is downtown Clearwater after all. However, everyone here seemed OK and I've not joined a cult so life remains good. I look forward to returning!
The braised pork bowl came with a pretty pitiful amount of pork but it did taste pretty good. Had a taiwan beer for $3.50 which is pretty cool.

Hidden in the wasteland known as "Downtown Oldsmar", this friendly and clean tavern deserves more traffic than it gets. They have a huge selection of beers, and some decent food to go along with it.

If you have never heard of "Downtown Oldsmar", don't feel bad... Use your GPS and life will be good.

Once again, the reliable Yelp community led me to another great business while on my last trip to Arizona. I was craving something cool and dismissed the fact that it was about 60 degrees out (yes, 60 degrees is considered cold for Hawaii locals)!  Frost Gelato has a nice large corner location in Tucson on the long and semi-rundown strip of Tanque Verde Road and is in a newer building than ones of their neighbors. 

Frost Gelato is housed in a bright clean and spacious space that offers both indoor and outdoor seating. My timing was perfect as there were only two other customers and I found a prime parking stall right in front of the shop and didn't have to wait in line. I was immediately greeted by two friendly employees and they were patient with me while I tried to decide on what flavor gelato I wanted. Of course I wanted all 38 flavors that they offer but I had to be reasonable! What helped was that they offered free samples and I finally decided on cheesecake and salted caramel. I got it in a cup and although their gelato is a bit pricey, it was well worth it because the flavors were on point and the serving was pretty generous. They stuck a wafer roll in the gelato which gave it a nice touch. 

They also have waffle cones and sugar cones including their Spizzico cones which are their miniature sugar cones. The next time I'm in the Tucson area, I will find a way to make it back to Frost Gelato. Why wouldn't I? They have the whole package-great customer service, a nice clean and spacious location with ample parking, and the gelato's top notch! 2 down, 36 flavors to go...

What everyone else said about this laundromat is true: it is exceedingly clean, well kept, safe, priced right and the people who work here are friendly and helpful. What more can you want from a laundromat?

I came here to get my duvet washed. I could have washed it here myself, but as someone smarter than me recently said: "Ain't no one got time for that." So I dropped it off with the friendly launderette who was sitting at the counter. She took my info, told me when I could pick it up, and asked me what kind of detergent to use. (She listed off like five different kinds. I chose unscented Tide.) Three hours and $19 dollars later, I have a clean, fresh, nicely folded duvet ready to be put back on my bed. My clean duvet also came in a nice plastic bag with a handle. It's a dang miracle, I tell you.

If my washer and dryer ever conk out, this will be the place I visit to wash and dry my laundry. In the mean time, I like knowing that I have a place where I can drop off random things that are too big for my washer, and they will come back sparkling (and it won't cost me a fortune).

Consider this a 3.5 - as a loyal and by loyal, I mean dangerously loyal customer of The Flying Cupcake I hate to be leaving anything less than 5 stars. (for the record, the location of my residence makes this loyalty inevitable). As of late, I've been disappointed by the new icing "methods." By this I mean we went from a 40% frosting/60% 'cake to 18% frosting/82% cake. With the icing not covering the entire surface of the top of the cake, how am I supposed to be certain that each bite of my Here Comes The Bride has a dabble of frosting? ...and with that, this review has taken a turn for the "first world problems" category.

A casual brunch spot between downtown and the wharf. You order at the counter, grab an emoji, and they bring your food to the table. We went for the build your own hash. They had some good options and our hash was really yummy. It had sweet potatoes, sage sausage, lots of veggies and topped with a poached egg and hollandaise sauce. It's also served with toast and a small green salad. I think it was around $14.

This was my very first Jimmy John's experience, and it won't be my last. I ordered the turkey sandwich, and it was really good. (Sliced deli turkey, mayo, lettuce and tomato. You can add cucumbers, but I didn't this time.) The bread is what makes it, though -- it's soft on the inside, and chewy on the outside. 

This particular location has a drive-thru, which is awesome. It was super quick to order, and we received our food just as fast.

I have come to this Chili's now 3 times in the past 6 months.  Both my experiences as a party of 3 warranted 4 stars but my experience this past weekend as a party of 7 to celebrate my birthday was not as good.

We were promptly greeted upon arrival and seated at a large booth.  They allowed us to order first for the two toddlers in the party which is always good.  Trouble is that the rest of us waited an additional 30 minutes to get our food after the toddlers were served.  We arrived before 5pm on a Sunday ANC the adults did not receive their entrees until 550PM.  By then, the toddlers were done and ready to run amok. 

The kid meals themselves were not easily handled by the children.  The bun on the cheeseburger meal was huge and outnumbered the patty at least by a ratio of 6:1.  The chicken strips were oddly enough in what appeared to be a thick need batter that my 5 year old could barely bite through.  Side note: kids' meals here do not come with fruit/cookie/dessert.  

For appetizers we shared the spinach artichoke dip (yummy) with warmed tortilla chips BUT our plate had what seemed to be the end of a bag with 50% broken so much that we could not put any dip on them.

Next, we shared the southwest egg rolls which were a big hit with everyone!  They come with a cilantro ranch style dipping sauce.

And we also shared the jalapeño cheese bites which came out like warm and not ooey gooey at all - it was as if they sat for 10 minutes before coming to us.  And as far as spice goes, I didn't notice any at all.  I'm not sure these would pass the test even if they were piping hot.

Finally... Dinner arrives.  I have to admit that my steak fajitas were excellent - moist, tender, flavorful BUT the $4 add on spicy garlic lime shrimp were a huge disappointment.  The shrimp were laid atop the skillet and not even the tiniest bit hot - they were room temp and rubbery :-( Pretty steep to charge $4 for rubbery room temp. Shrimp.

Also in out party, a 6 oz. sirloin was enjoyed cooked to perfection, ribs, and lettuce wraps.

Overall the food was pretty good but it was the service or lack there of for timing that was a complete bust.

Ended the meal without dessert because by that time the children were ready to leave.

Overall, I'd come back again in a smaller group but it was a bust for my party of 7.

John Besh restaurants never seem to disappoint. Luke is one of his best because it is casual with great food at a great price. Ate here with some friends last night, we had the roasted chicken, the fried oyster and avocado salad, bread pudding and creme brûlée for dessert. All was top notch with flavor that is New Orleans own. Next time I go though I must try the seafood courtboullion which is Besh's version of a local classic. You just can't go wrong with John Besh.

#700 review. Rare Ethnic food 1 - Guatemalan cuisine. 

I choose Rincon Guatemalteco to start my 700 series in yelp review. I will start my ethnic review for next several reviews. The restaurant name meaning "in the corner of Guatemala." If you like get inside of this corner, please check them out. 

The food is an authentic, special flavor, fantastic prep work, and unique. I was surprised by taste. Today we order the Tostadas de Frito. This is an appetizer. It is tostadas top with black bean paste and sprinkle with dry cheese. My wife mistaken the black bean as chocolate. You can smell the heavy fermented cheese smell before you eat. 

The tamale we have is wrap around chicken pieces. The tamale paste is different than many tamale. The taste is more to rice paste than the bean paste texture. 

We have the main dish as Carne Adobada. It is marinated pork with rice and black bean. I would describe the best black bean paste that I have. It cook with garlic and make this bean paste stand out from other black bean preparation. 

The two drink that we have are Rosa Jamaica and 
Tamarind. Rosa Jamaica is the best drink in the Bay Area. I have try many place for this drink. But this one stand out.

Please call before you go. Close on Wednesday. Tuesday close early. Weekday 9am to 6 pm. Weekend 9am to 7 pm.

Most all Save-On's are fairly uniformed: Great deli and cheese section, nice assortment of seafood, outstanding bulk foods selection and a bigger section for organic/natural foods then most other chain grocers. The one thing that makes this Save-On stand out from others is that it has a salad bar section and an indoor and patio section where you can sit down and eat. And, the salad bar is really, really good! (pssst, and fairly less expensive then a place down the street!) I also like the large selection of flowers and bouquets at the front of the store.

So many good things to say about Beawon - they're such a pleasant atmosphere of friendly servers, inviting (and well-lit) dining room and their FOOD.  

Bon chons --- awesome!  The different kinds we had were some sort of potato salad, kimchi (of course), fishcake & a few others that are currently slipping my mind.  Loved 'em all & they were quite nice about refilling for seconds :).

I tip-toed past my usual kalbi & soondubu favorites and ventured on instead for some kkanpunggi (a spicy version of sweet & sour chicken) & Jjamppong, a sort of ramen-type dish with seafood.  I really liked the jjamppong, but preferred the broth tossed with rice instead of noodles (perhaps this is a change they could make for you per request?).  Happily slurped up all the goodness, seafood was really fresh, couldn't have asked for a better heart-warming meal.

The coffee in seven words: Mmmm, mm, yum, nice, yum, delicious, mmmmmmmmmmm.

The service: Down home and sweet. I'd call it neighborhoodly, especially for being in a hotel and on an otherwise desolate block.

The locals: Enough of them to enhance the homey feel

The food offerings: Non-existent. Don't let those dry, too-sweet muffins tempt you.

I would give this 6 stars if I could. Where to begin?

The BRUNCH is off the hook, same price as Jeannine's but you're eating in an art museum with French tapestries, elegant flatware, beauty in every corner of the room. 

I don't know how ANYONE could give this less than 5 stars. Now, at dinner it's apparently pricey. Duh. This is a fine dining institution in Santa Barbara and it's French with a star LA chef and the owners spared no expense in the remodeling of the casual, not divey but not nice, State and A which managed to stay in business a couple decades in spite of the subpar food. 

It turns out the owners have grown daughters in NYC and I have so enjoyed my afternoon here. My iPhone 5 makes a hotspot so I'm blogging before I meet a friend at 4 and swim to work off the potato daphinois--don't ask about the fat content--a sinful tower of thinly sliced potatoes with cheese and oil and all manner of terrible things which taste wonderful. 

My scramble--a bargain at 12.95--included perfect carmelized onions, roasted peppers, spinach and a hint of goat cheese--and I will dream of this till my next brunch here after Chicago/Michigan trip. 

After 5 cups of coffee to wake me up from horrible asthmatic night, I had a glass of the Ballard Pinot for dessert Nice but no better than the cheaper--9/glass--Kenwood Cab which I think is quite a respectable Cab for the money. 

The coffee is good but if you're like my father who, due to his time in the military, requires coffee which scalds the tongue, you will need to pull a Dad and ask them to nuke it in the "radar oven." It's not hot but I don't really care as it tasted good and did the trick: that is, it enabled me to have two glasses of wine after a miserable night of wheezing, hacking and blowing my nose. 

I cannot say enough for Maggie's and am so happy it's here in SB. I will come before my next show at the Granada for dinner at the bar. I have a subscription (see Yelp) and come alone.

PS I haven't eaten here at dinner yet but every single person who brought me food or booze was fabulous and I got to chat at length with the spectacular, smart owner with whom it turns out I have quite a bit culturally in common. I have no clue what people are talking about re service. It's not crowded but it's not empty and they have taken magnificent care of me.

Fresh certainly understands the meaning of the the term Fresh and has successfully embraced and implemented the use of fresh ingredients into all of their menu items. Carefully selecting their fruit for their smoothies, ensuring it is at its peak ripeness and freshness, and working closely with local vendors to bring the best quality into their kitchen, I have no doubt that Fresh will be a top favorite among locals. They may not have the largest menu with complex offerings, but that is exactly what I like about this place. I've had the pleasure of enjoying the Strawberry Chicken Salad, the Chicken Tacos, The Panino with Chicken, roasted Peppers and aioli, and a blissful sip of the smoothie my boyfriend ordered. (p.s. all this food was consumed over 2 visits). Th, the only word that came to mind with every bite was "fresh." It is rare to be wow'd by the intense freshness of ingredients when eating out. The strawberries on the salad were bright red and juicy as can be, the tacos were packed with chipotle flavor yet light, the panino was decadent yet simple, and the smoothie was all tropical, tangy freshness! 

Simple menu + fresh handpicked ingredients + passion = FRESH= perfection

It's Sunday night and the Cards are in the playoffs, we're not cooking or going out for dinner. We didn't want pizza, Chinese or any type of fast food. We were at a a loss for ideas. I was searching Yelp for ideas and checked to see if Joey B's did carry- out and to my surprise they did.  We checked the menu and made the call. 

We ordered two of their Blue Plate Specials; Country Fried Chicken and Homemade Meatloaf. Both came with mashed potatoes and gravy and corn on the cob. The meatloaf also came with a side salad that was humongous, it was big enough for both of us to share. My Homemade Meatloaf  with a brown gravy truly had to down home taste. It is way better then other "Blue Plate Specials" near and on "The Hill". My SO enjoyed his Country Fried Chicken and its white gravy topping. Their great taste surprised us coming from a sports bar which is known for burgers and pizza. 

I think Joey B's will be getting some more carryout orders from us.  They're close, the prices are right and the food is good.

massive margaritas.
don't remember much else
family-run, had some combination dinner that didn't stand out.

Sticky, licky, sucky, messy, dirty and wet.  There is something better than sex for sale in Port Richmond, and no, it's not heroin.

Bonk's crabs.  Blue crabs in insanely spicy  briny murky seawater were the best I've had in Philly.  They were delivered less than hot, which irked me straight off, but were so tasty I forgave it.

Fries were crisp and well-seasoned, with a side of melted white cheese that smoothed out the hot heat of the crab broth.

Wings were good,  of the well-done school.  Not the best thing on the table, but respectable.

Deep-fried beer battered crab nuggets were hot grease perfection, dipped in a side of tartar sauce.

Dinner for three with a beer each, four jumbo $8 crabs and many fried basket things was $23 each.    Better than sex, but you still need a shower afterwards.

Finally made it to the famed falafel truck.  I believe the official name is Christos's Falafel.  I'd heard the stories and knew that I should plan to wait and just trust in what he is serving.

Turns out you don't even order here.  Little was said to anyone during my visit.  "Gus" cooks, refills the charcoal in his grill, and serves up falafel, grilled chicken, and salads/sides.  There's no menu. Walk up to the truck, and he'll put together a styrofoam container of everything unless you specify that you want a sandwich.  Otherwise, you need not say a word.  He didn't even ask me for money, assuming I already knew the price (it's not posted anywhere).  

My plate was $10 and could easily feed two.  The chicken was flavorful, covered in spices. The salad was fine, with fresh green lettuce, a bean dish, and something tropical I couldn't identify (was that plantain?).  My palate was confused after all the Greek-style meat.

But the falafel...oh, the falafel.  It was unlike anything I've eaten.  It was so bright--there are a lot of fresh herbs in there.  It was light and airy yet crispy on the outside. The texture was unusual but excellent.  I can't for the life of me figure out what it is that makes it so different. Does he whip the bean mixture first?   Whatever it is, it works.

I got to visit Whitebox for lunch for the first time. I was in the mood for a sandwich with more than one kind of meat, so I went for the Italian. It had all the ham, cheese and salami I wanted! But I have to say that the veggies and dressing it was topped with was a bit too vinegar-y for my tastes, so I don't know that I'd get that one again. 

My father-in-law knows about my crazy sweet tooth, so he picked up a (guten-free) chocolate chocolate chip cookie for me. It was amazing!!! Definitely one of the better cookies I've ever had and probably the best I've found in St. Louis. It was warm, soft and the chocolate chips were all gooey. I was really nice and shared it with my husband. That was really hard for me...
Almond horn was a pricey $5 compared to Swiss Haus, and just about as good.

The location is fantastic. Just far enough removed from the mess of Bourbon Street, but still close enough for you party people. Pretty much everything is within walking distance - even the conference center on the river front is only a 20 minute walk away. 

I enjoyed my stay here, and really appreciated the fact that they let me check-in at 8AM on the morning of my arrival even though check-in time is typically not until 4PM. I also loved the room that I was given (a corner room on one of the newly added floors). It was spacious and the bed was so, so comfortable. It was like sleeping on clouds, I kid you not. The only thing that kind of irked me was the separate elevator that was needed to access the top 3 floors - it made the whole commute up and down the building quite a hassle. 

All in all, I would highly recommend this Wyndham for either business or pleasure. They make things very convenient for you - with cab pickups, printing services at the front desk, etc.

Upscale bar/restaurant with an adjoining elegant dining area. The establishment is large, has a full bar equipped with TV's and fresh oysters clearly on display for you to witness the art of shucking.

Daily Chef Specials are available Monday-Friday. I visited on a Monday and therefore went with the Honey Tabasco Chicken special. However, I started with a cup of Crawfish Bisque soup; a delicious choice to get my palate fired up for the main course. The Honey Tabasco Chicken was the perfect combination of sweet & spicy atop a succulent lightly battered chicken breast, accompanied by red beans and rice, putting a southern twist on a classic dish. I enjoyed it immensely but could only eat a small portion. My eyes are always bigger than my tummy. Jackson, my server, was a real gent & wrapped the remains for me. 

Lüke is a perfect NOLA spot for date night, business meetings and hour happy.

~Christy

Made it to Luke's for dinner and the crabmeat ravioli is AMAZING.  However I'm knocking off a star because the place was a zoo.  

The next table was a 50th birthday party of 9 adults; one of the women was literally yelling at the top of her voice.  With tile/hardwood floors and tin ceilings, the volume in the restaurant almost ruined our meal.  It was exceedingly difficult to carry on a conversation at our table of 5 in between the shrieks next to us.  

Other dishes at our table were the redfish (w/ the crabmeat), the vanilla duck, shrimp & grits, and the shrimp farci.  Everyone thought their food was lovely...if only the atmosphere had been as nice.

This is a pretty amazing bar, it has the feeling of a true neighborhood bar, and like Kelly B. said, "that happens to be downtown." If I lived downtown, I'd have a name plate on one of the bar-stools.  I would never drink at home alone, I would be here with all my friends. This is the "Cheers" of St. Louis. 

The drinks here are cheap and with the free pour that the bartenders do here, they are worth every cent. Some of their rail liquor is what some bars offer as "call brands". 

The party room downstairs is a great place for a friends gathering to celebrate special occasions. I only got to sample a few food offerings the night I visited,  from a small buffet. What I did sample was good bar grub, but I want to go back and taste what I here is, "the best cheeseburger". 

Jack I'm giving you fair warning, I'm going to be back.

My wonderful boyfriend bought me a Groupon for this place ages ago and I kind of kept forgetting to use it.  Lo and behold it expires September 8, so I knew I needed to get a move-on.  My biggest dilemma was how to use the $45 gift certificate.  I have a place that does my hair and I never cheat on them (see also my review for East End Salon, amazing), I'm not much of a mani-pedi girl, and I feel guilty getting massages without my other half, so I decided to opt for waxing.  

I never let anyone near my eyebrows, which I prefer to keep on the thicker side and I shape them myself, leg waxing at the end of summer seemed silly and shaving takes me all of 30 seconds in the shower, so that left me with the bikini wax option.  I've never gotten a bikini wax and thought I'd like to try a brazilian.  This all seemed like such a great idea when it was an appointment on my calendar, but when the day came I found I was actually terrified.  How much is it going to hurt?  Is it going to be super awkward?  Why on earth did I ever think this was a good idea?

Thusly, full of apprehension, I tracked the salon down (3rd floor of the Rittenhouse Hotel, on the West side of the park.  Google maps is somewhat misleading in its pin placement for the address) and entered a peaceful oasis of calming music and Aveda-tinged air. I didn't have long to wait before my waxing specialist turned up to put me out of my misery.  Her name is Rachel and she is a goddess.  

Rachel was very direct and matter-of-fact in explaining the process, positioning, etc which I really appreciate.  I'm not exactly shy, but having your bits uncovered for some stranger to be maneuvering around is somewhat unsettling.  She made me feel completely at ease throughout the procedure by keeping up a friendly chatter.  We found a topic of common interest and chit-chatted while she ripped those strips away one by one.  It took about 35 minutes and while there were a few particularly painful moments, it really wasn't nearly as bad as I had anticipated.  I mean, having hair in the tenderest parts of your body ripped out by brute force and hot wax isn't exactly a peaceful relaxing afternoon, but it went by fast and at no point was I tempted to throw in the towel.  She alternated sides with each rip so it helped the pain to ebb between pulls and also gave me the option of calling it off and still being symmetrical.

All in all it was a positive experience.  I picked up some special exfoliating/calming stuff for the post-wax ouchies when I ponied up for the rest of the bill, and was quite surprised that the wax itself was $65!  Dang!  That's what I pay for a haircut and I'm so cheap I only do that twice a year at best.  The Groupon defrayed the cost down so I only had to pay the $20 difference, but at that price I can't see myself doing this more than once a year.  When I do, though, I'll be coming back here and asking for Rachel by name.

This is your typical McDonald's, so there really isn't too much that can be said.  This one is open 24 hours and is good for a late night snack.

I was coming home from an event held in St. Pete and needed a quick soda. The wait for the drive-thru took longer than usual. But, this is to be expected late on a weekend night. 

Not a huge fan of this drive-thru. The setup is strange. It is a weird windy drive-thru that you practically have to be Mario Andretti to maneuver your car through the path. 

They screwed up my order, but somehow I knew that would happen. It was very late and I didn't want deal with the hassle of letting the restaurant know. So, I just decided to deal it with. Lesson learned, check my order before leaving the drive-thru, especially at this location.

August 17, 2013 Saturday - dinner 05:45 PM
2 adults 

Atmosphere - 5 star
Food - 5 stars
Service - 5 stars

Background - Finished herding the cats, okay my friends after the afternoon wine walk.

Atmosphere - Sat on the patio, old sidewalk around their restaurant.  It was fun watching the people come from the parking garage elevator.

Food
  Appetizer - none.

  Drinks - Strange but I only ordered water.  What a shame, they have great beer.  But after walking around the afternoon I was parched.  Our waitress was good at bringing the water every ten or so, I was jugging it.

  My Main Course - The Sante Fa, a chicken sandwich.  It had avocado so I had to go for it.  Loved the pasilla pepper on top of the chicken, it was grilled to add the smoke taste.  They also added smoked mozzarella for more smoke.  Great sandwich

  Dessert - Skipped it.

Service - She was there with the water, what I needed.  Great service and she was very helpful when one of the ladies in our party did not like their meal.

Future - Been here before, doubt I will stop now.

Upscale and fancy are the two words that you'll never see in the same sentence with this restaurant's name. What you will hear consistently is how good the food is.... I stop in here 2-3 times per month. The ladies that work here are very nice, welcoming, and helpful. The food is always hot and tasty. I've never had a  disappointing meal here. The  lunch specials are reasonably priced, and the meal size is usually more than you can eat at the time. When I'm passing through, I always search for more Chinese restaurants, but always wind up pulling into this lot. Its really meal good enough to tell someone about.

My girlfriend and I just had a delightful lunch.

Lunch specials are $9.95, which includes an appetizer, an entrée and a beverage.

Our server was friendly and knowledgeable, and he gave us plenty of time to decide. There were many choices.

She got arancini, spinach ravioli and iced tea. And she ordered a dinner-sized portion of baked cannelloni to take home for dinner.

I got phyllo cigars, chicken madeira and Diet Coke.

Beverage refills were spot-on throughout our meal.

When the appetizers came out, they were fresh out of the fryer -- hot, but not killer hot. The arancini were sitting on a tomato-cheese sauce. The phyllo cigars were served with a tomato-based sauce.

We shared, so I got an arancini, and she got 1-1/2 phyllo cigars. They were both tremendously flavorful and full-bodied. The phyllo cigars were stuffed with dill feta. Besides risotto, the arancini were filled with gorgonzola and steak.

Our entrees were equally impressive, but less eaten. We were both kinda full -- not stuffed, but comfortable.

I took two bites of my tender chicken, which had a tomato and mushroom sauce, and two bites of zucchini (cut on the bias rather thickly to maintain its integrity) beautifully sautéed to the point of lovely browned crispness.

She took two bites of one ravioli, proclaimed it excellent, and we both took home a bunch o' food.

By the time we left, place was pretty filled up . . . just like we were.

The last time I went to a Penang was in Boston.  So when I came to Chicago, I was so disappointed that the Penang was closed due to a fire.  Luckily they had a Penang in Philadelphia so I was reunited with delicious Malaysian food!  This restaurant is a chain, but the food is delicious! I cant remember the exact dish that I ordered, but the food had great flavors and not a lot of heat (the appetizer was a curry dip with roti bread). Service was good but hovered a lot.  Plus, the restaurant was not full of people but we felt very rushed.  They were quick to give us the bill but were not quick in settling the bill. Weird.

I've had good service here. Quite helpful and friendly. They can get busy at times. But will take care of you when your time comes. 

Decent selection of phones. They stock the T-Mobile Tuesday freebies. Our dog loves her T-mobile bowtie and we have T-mobile umbrellas and super hero capes. They come in handy. 

Can you hear me now?

Best Chinese restaurant in Reno. We tried to go there before for dinner but the wait was insane. Got there right when they opened for lunch  and they quickly filled up after.

Great flavor for all dishes. Looooooved their stinky tofu...best dish of the day. Perfectly fried and seasoned. 

We had 8 dishes along w/ drinks and it only came out to around $60ish. 10% off w/ check in if you order over $40. Awesome!

Standard beer and pub food fare. We tried four different beers: the mango IPA, the kolsch, the Brett Saison, and the Wit. We weren't impressed by any, but the Wit was our favorite out of the four. For food, we ordered corn fritters. The fritters were fine, but the sauce that came with them was a totally gross, fully congealed excuse for a queso. I held the tub of it upside down - nothing, it didn't drip. We were in the area and wanted to grab a beer, but I definitely wouldn't go out of my way to go back here!

I believe this is the first time I am giving a "restaurant" at an airport 5 stars!! Reason... huge smiles on everyone's face and great service which was great to see early in the morning. Definitely made me smile. Oh and the food was pretty good. I had the Reno quiche which hit the spot.

So I usually hate Yelp reviews that rant about the service. Because, I honestly think that if you're a true food lover, you wouldn't give a rats behind about service. Really good food speaks for itself. And it you wanted to be a big baby and spoon feed, you would have went to your mama's place. So with that aside, let's talk about Germantown Pub.

Food isn't good. Everything I've had here has been frozen and reheated/refried. From the fries to the catfish to the chicken tenders. Nothing here is made fresh in-house. So expect things to be overseasoned and oversalted to cover up for lack of freshness. And let's not forget how dry the food usually is. Like your great aunt's cooch, this food hasn't been moist in ages. 

The real insult to injury was the service our group received tonight. Our group of 12 came here for trivia which is actually really fun. And we're not the standard a-holes that move from our original seats, make tons of modifications to the menu and confuse our server. 

So, I was pretty freaking shocked when the server asked me what "number you were" like I was cattle or standing in line at the DMV when I tried to order another beer. When I asked her to clarify, she stated "I gave you a number when you sat down." Um no, you didn't because I would have actually asked you what you mean by number. I've worked in to service industry before so I understand large groups may be difficult but ultimately it's your JOB to remember who orders what. Blaming the customer for your lack of memorization makes the experience uncomfortable for everyone involved. She also claimed my friend's food would "be here in a moment" then 20 minutes later came back and accused him of never ordering it in the first place. Like seriously, we all heard him order it and then heard you confirm his order...twice. She also told me "don't get the Thai sauce on the chicken tenders...it's terrible." so I went with plain chicken tenders and just honey mustard on the side. But guess who ends up with the terrible Thai sauce on her chicken tenders, this girl. But I didn't even bother to send it back and ate my dry Thai sauced chicken tenders anyways because you can tell when things just weren't going ever be rectified. Also, not to the server's fault but due poor planning, ALL BUT ONE of the happy hour draft beers was available going into the 1st hour of trivia. Like, you guys didn't realize that as a bar on an event night you may want to have more beer available?

Short summary is, come here for the trivia and good company. Expect the happy hour beer to run out. Avoid the long red-headed server. And eat dinner elsewhere beforehand.

Midtown is the nicest liquor store in the area, in my opinion. When you walk in, classical music is playing and they just have that high end feel while browsing. They also know what the hell they are talking about people!

They have a fabulous liquor and wine selection, and are eager to offer a suggestion or opinion on what they carry. Complaints... they aren't the most cost efficient place in town (though not crazily so, just noticeable) and since times have been a bit tighter financially for me lately, I feel like a bit of a bum shopping here for my box o' wine or cheap selections. 

You know what I mean. I actually wanted a boxed wine recommendation (I prefer bottles but you've gotta do what you gotta do) but I noticed I wasn't approached once when I was in that area, whereas other sections will get you some customer service. Oh well, I guess it was less embarrassing to just grab my box and get the heck out of there before I was judged too harshly. 

But I do love shopping here, especially if I can afford something of the nicer variety!

The chicken here is amazing!  The last time I ad authentic Peruvian rotisserie chicken was at malecon in NY. The skin is crispy and flavorful and the meat juicy. I ordered a whole chicken meaning to save half but...  Oh well, it'll be time to hit the gym. After my sat gorge fest at a NY style deli of course but I digress. Anyhow great food and friendly people. I'll definitely be back because I love my meat.

What a cute party place environment in little ol Clementon. My Imported boyfriend actually suggested trying here.

Super friendly service (Veronica) and a nice huge horchata along w chips & guac - both v good (guac a tiny  bit too spicy for moi)  - started us off. 

I had chicken fajitas that were awesome - nice tender chicken, peppers and onions AND slices of guacamole! YUMMY!!!!

Vince had chicken chilaquiles, which he enjoyed - esp the rich red sauce. 

The desserts looked wonderful but we were too full to partake.

A group of us stopped by this past weekend; there were 4 of us (myself, my boyfriend, and his friend with his girlfriend) When we got there, we were told it was a 20 minute wait. So we tell them, we're going to wait at the bar and the girl says "So I'll take your name off the list then?" Not the brightest crayon in the box was she?

But we sat at the bar and each ordered a drink while we waited. Rob and I each got the Sky Juice drink (Blue Curacao, Sprite, and your choice of spirit with cream of coconut) The bartender told us the Sky Pineapple was the most popular so we tried it and it was awesome! Plus, our drinks were so strong that by the time we got our table about 5-10 min later, we were already starting to feel the effects!

The food was decent; the two guys and other girl ordered burgers (or in her case, burger sliders) while I had shrimp and french fries. But it all pales in comparison to what I ordered for dessert: warm apple crisp! Was it the best I've ever had? Nah. but I was so excited that it was an option that I didn't really care.

It's a fun place if you're with a group of friends or something; it's almost the beach version of a burger joint.

Had dinner here last night and it was just OK.
Greek salad that came with dinner was good but lettuce was overly wet.  (Odd.)

Chicken Francese was swimming (drowning) in a heavy buttery sauce.  The chicken itself (I pulled it out of the sauce and put it on another plate) was good though.

Not a holy grail, but a much needed place in a culinary wasteland.

Once draped in white tablecloths and awash in upscale "pre-Hispanic" influenced Mexican plates, Xochitl has reconcepted into a more casual and inexpensive cantina.  Cutting down the wall that divided the dining room from the bar unites the room, spreading that buzzy vibe we like so well across the whole space.  

The Happy Hour here is still amazing -- $5 margs always made with premium tequila and fresh-squeezed lime juice, discount beer.  The uber-special runs Thursday night from 10 p.m. - 1 a.m., when happy hour prices reign on drinks (in the cozy downstairs lounge) and the ENTIRE menu is half-price.  You read it right, pals, half-price everything. 

Queso fundido, ceviche, pork cheek tacos, churros, oh my.  Service is always friendly and accomodating -- they dropped the tablecloths and prices, but not the quality or knowledge.

This is the seafood market side of Harbor Seafood & Oyster Bar restaurant.  They sell boiled crawfish, shrimp and crabs along with fresh and frozen of the same along with fish.  I eat at Harbor Seafood & Oyster Bar all the time and it stays open later than the market side but if you want something boiled to go or to take home and cook yourself the market can provide you with most of the seafood items you can eat on the restaurant side along with quite a few they don't.

This combo candy shop and gift shop has some delicious confections to test your will power.  Though I noticed the variety of gifts and cards, I had my attention drawn to the chocolates counter.  (They have a variety of other types of candies including a jelly bean wall and some other fruity type treats.)

After looking over the displays a couple times, I asked and found out that you can buy the chocolates by the piece or by the pound.  I thought it best to go with individual pieces and limited my purchase so that my waistline stayed relatively the same size as when I started the day.  I decided to get a pecan snapper in milk chocolate (snapper = turtle), a cashew snapper in milk chocolate, and a dark chocolate covered pretzel.  
Because the pieces are handmade, they are on the pricey side.  (After tax, it was nearly $8!)

The flavor was really good.  The snappers were fairly large compared to the ones you see in those assortment boxes.  They were filled with nuts and creamy gooey caramel.  The only problem was that since it was a hot day, I had a bit of a mess as the chocolate melted.  (Fear not, I am not above licking my fingers to savor the last bit of it!)

Overall, I would recommend this place if you have some will power or otherwise, a very deep wallet!

Review #1214

**** 3 1/2 Stars****

We came to. Effoc's for brunch on our last day in Delaware. It's a small cafe in Wilmington. My friend described it perfectly: good food, good prices, but the place smells of their cooking so be prepared to smell like brunch. Heeding her warning, we opted to sit outside. Luckily it was a nice day. 

We looked over the menu and then placed our orders inside. I opted for the vegetarian egg white omelette with lots of vegetables! Loved the spinach and avocado! They also have several beverage options. I chose coffee and the peach mango smoothie. Cool and refreshing. 

The prices are good and staff is friendly. Effoc's does smell like their food on the inside though. Not a negative, just a comment.

I was attending a conference at this hotel in April and the pictures on the website made it look very nice.  However, once I arrived I realized what a beautiful property it really is.  My room overlooked Tampa Bay and was modern and very comfortable - great bed and great shower.  The staff was extremely friendly and parking was very easy.  It is also conveniently located to the airport making it very handy for the business traveler.  Highly recommended hotel when staying in the Tampa Bay area.

Lit-erally one of the cutest wine bars in the city and a perfect 104th Street hot spot. This Italian style wine bar is always packed and buzzing. Although, it is hard not to be busy in a place that is so, in a word, Lit-tle. With seating for around 30, not the most comfortable in the world, mind you, it does well to have a reservation if you are going to be a guest.  The Italian menu reads like Lit-erature (I know, I couldn't help it!), sparkling with Italian classics such as antipastos, olives, flat breads and pastas.  The wine list is excellent as well, as one would expect from a venue de vino. The deconstructed environment is sparsely decorated with a few paintings and Lit-hographs (I swear, that is the last one) by local artists.

So go fall in love with Lit. What can I say... sometimes, it's all in the name!

The burgers take time to come out because they're made fresh. The fries weren't as hot as tthey could have been, but the food was made to my specs and I didn't have a problem with that.  The diet coke was a good mix and all in all, II'd come back.

I have not been to this restaurant in years, but back when my step father and I used to visit this place, the food was pretty good and the service was on par as well. The price was not too expensive either, worth eating at if you are in the area.

First of all, I'm lactose intolerant so when my friend drove me here on a stormy day before my flight back to Vegas, I was hesitant.  Is it going to be worth the pain and suffering?

First thing I saw was "NUTELLA" - you can't go wrong with that. They have a whole selection of different kinds of chocolate ice cream and that's the first thing you'll see when you come in. It was like they were holding my hand and asking me to stay so I did. The next panel was a variety of ice cream and sorbet flavors you won't see at grocery stores such as Green Fairy (absinthe with chocolate and candied orange), Calamansi, Lavender Honey, Champagne Violette, etc. I was so overwhelmed by the many options so I decided to try 1 safe flavor (Nutella Banana) and 1 weird flavor (Green Fairy) without knowing I could do a sampler. The waffle cone was delish and freshly made. Now, make sure you bring cash.

A few minutes later my stomach was cursing at me but I didn't care! I'll definitely come back to NOLA for some Creole Creamery. I'm having withdrawals right now and I only had it yesterday.

If EVER there was a store that had -too- much, Bed, Bath and beyond is the perfect example of that store.  They have floor to rafter and just about every square inch of floor space - save that what you would call isles filled with merchandise. 

And given that this is Christmas shopping season, well, it's doubly so! Yes, if you've seen it on TV, you can find it there. Do you want the Veg-o-matic Spaghetti maker? They have it.  Do you want Poo-Pouri?Its there too, and in multiple scents. The sweeping craze of Adult Colouring is big as is STAR WARS. Oh lard, lets talk about Star Wars. If it's got Kylo Ren or the Chrome Storm Trooper on it, its there. 

They have pillows and comforters, they have everything you need. It's packed floor to beam with everything and more. I don't enjoy the pace, or the place, but it is what it is, and they will print you out a Gift receipt if you forget to ask for one when they're ringing things up.
